Most laws in a legal system require two parts:
1. Actus Reus (the committing of the act) 2. Mens Rea (an intent to commit that act. In some cases, you need to know that it is wrong)
Some crimes are 'strict liability'. This means that you only need the 'actus reus'. I think having sex with a child is a strict liability crime. So, even if you done everything to check they were of age, it is still a crime to sleep with them and you will be punished.
But yeah, for most crimes, you need to prove that the person knew they were doing something wrong. Theft, for example, if I took a biscuit thinking it was my biscuit that I left behind earlier, should I be charged with theft? No. However, if I knew I was stealing that biscuit from somebody, I should be.
